review.title: Cross-model convolutional neural network for multiple modality data representation
review.abstract: A novel data representation method of convolutional neural net- work (CNN) is proposed in this paper to represent data of different modalities. We learn a CNN model for the data of each modality to map the data of differ- ent modalities to a common space, and regularize the new representations in the common space by a cross-model relevance matrix. We further impose that the class label of data points can also be predicted from the CNN representa- tions in the common space. The learning problem is modeled as a minimiza- tion problem, which is solved by an augmented Lagrange method (ALM) with updating rules of Alternating direction method of multipliers (ADMM). The experiments over benchmark of sequence data of multiple modalities show its advantage.

sections.heading: 3 Experiments
sections.text: In this section, we evaluate the proposed Cross-Model CNN Method (CMCNN) experimentally, comparing it with some other Cross-Model representation methods that also include database methods, and describing the data sets as follows: The first data set we used is the wiki dataset of two modalities that are image and text. In total, there are 2,866 documents in this dataset. For each document, there is an image and a text. To represent each image, we split the image into small patches and use a window to extract features from adjacent patches. SIFT's visual features are extracted from each patch. The number of classes in this dataset is 10. A text / image is considered relevant to another text / image if they are in the same class. NUS-WIDE.

sections.heading: 4 Conclusions
sections.text: In this paper, we propose to learn revolutionary models to solve the problem of cross-model data representation and retrieval problems. We propose to map the data of different modalities to a common space, and in this common space, classification and retrieval can be carried out. Also, in the common space, data of different modalities can be compared, and we use cross-model relevance regulation to compare the differences of the data points. To map the sequences of different modalities, we propose to use the CNN model with multiple filters and max pooling operations. Different modalities have different filter bases, but can map the sequences to a common space. A linear classifier is applied to the results of the cross-model CNN to predict the class names, and we also regulate the results of the CNN by a cross-model relevance term. Experiments on the benchmark data sets show its advantage over the existing cross-model data representation.
